nominalpy.connection package

Submodules

nominalpy.connection.credentials module

class nominalpy.connection.credentials.Credentials(url: str = 'https://api.nominalsys.com', port: int = None, access: str = '')

Bases: object

The Credentials class stores the credential access to the Nominal API for making API calls to the server. This can allow for both a remote or a local server call.

access_key: str = ''

Defines the access key if it exists for the API. This is required for cloud based API calls.

is_local: bool = False

Defines whether the URL is a localhost one or not; used to ensure that a connection is valid.

is_valid() → bool

Returns whether the credentials are valid. This does not check if the credentials are valid to a connection, more that the information has been added correctly.

Returns:

A valid credential flag

Return type:

bool

port: int = None

Defines the port for the API. If left as None, no port will be used.

session_id: str = None

This defines the session ID for the current working session, stored for public API keys.

url: str = ''

Defines the base URL for the API. If empty, it assumes that the URL is localhost.

nominalpy.connection.helper module

This modules assists with some helper functions for defining what values can be turned into JSON and whether GUID IDs are valid. This also includes some methods for serializing and deserializing JSON data to standard formats, including numpy ndarrays and datetimes.

nominalpy.connection.helper.contains(data: dict, *args) → bool

Determines if a particular set of parameter names exist within a dictionary and returns whether all arguments exist.

Parameters:

  • data (dict) – The raw dictionary data containing some arguments

  • args (list) – A list of argument names to check within the dictionary

Returns:

A flag indicating that all the arguments exist within the dictionary

Return type:

bool

nominalpy.connection.helper.deserialize(param: object) → object

Attempts to deserialize a particular object based on the data within the dictionary and returns the data in a specific way that is expected within Python. This means that numpy arrays will be returned if they contain the correct data.

Params param:

The parameter that should be deserialized

Returns:

The object from the deserialization

Return type:

object

nominalpy.connection.helper.is_valid_guid(guid: str) → bool

Determines if a parsed GUID, as a string, is valid. This will ensure that it is of the correct format.

Parameters:

guid (str) – The unique GUID of the object, in the correct form

Returns:

A flag whether the GUID is valid

Return type:

bool

nominalpy.connection.helper.jsonify(data: dict, array: bool = False) → str

Converts a particular data as a dictionary to string using the JSON payload and has an optional parameter to wrap the data inside of an array.

Parameters:

  • data (dict) – The raw set of dictionary data that will be returned to a JSON string

  • array (bool) – A flag whether to transform the data within an array framework

Returns:

The JSON data in a string form

Return type:

str

nominalpy.connection.helper.serialize(params: dict) → dict

Attempts to create a JSON dictionary based on a series of parameters that are parsed in from the user. This will construct the data from numpy arrays and other data formats that need to be serialized correctly.

Parameters:

params (dict) – A list of arguments from the object that should be serialized

Returns:

A full dictionary in a JSON format of the serialized data

Return type:

dict

nominalpy.connection.helper.serialize_object(obj: object) → dict

Attempts to create a JSON serialized object based on a single object that is parsed into the system. This will check based on standard python types including numpy arrays and datetimes.

Parameters:

obj (object) – An object to be serialized

Returns:

A full dictionary in a JSON format of the serialized data

Return type:

dict

nominalpy.connection.http module

This modules assists with having some helper functions for requesting data from the API and ensuring the data is in the correct form.

nominalpy.connection.http.create_web_exception(code: int) → None

This method creates an exception based on the status code that exists. This is useful for any status code that is not 200, which is an OK status.

Parameters:

code (int) – The HTTP request code from the request object

nominalpy.connection.http.delete_request(credentials: Credentials, url: str, data: str = None, params: dict = {}) → dict

Creates a DELETE request with some suffix URL data and returns the result of the request in a JSON form. If there was an error, then a None will be returned. This requires valid credentials to be passed through.

Parameters:

  • credentials (Credentials) – The valid API credentials to make the API call with

  • url (str) – The sub-URL to make the HTTP DELETE request to, added to the credentials URL

  • data (str) – A set of data optional parameters that are passed into the request

  • params (dict) – A dictionary of values to parse into the DELETE request with associated values

Returns:

The JSON data from the DELETE request if the request was valid

Return type:

dict

nominalpy.connection.http.get_request(credentials: Credentials, url: str, params: dict = {}) → dict

Creates a GET request with some suffix URL data and returns the result of the request in a JSON form. If there was an error, then a None will be returned. This requires valid credentials to be passed through.

Parameters:

  • credentials (Credentials) – The valid API credentials to make the API call with

  • url (str) – The sub-URL to make the HTTP GET request to, added to the credentials URL

  • params (dict) – A dictionary of values to parse into the GET request with associated values

Returns:

The JSON data from the GET request if the request was valid

Return type:

dict

nominalpy.connection.http.handle_request_data(response: Response) → dict

Handles the standard request data created from a HTTP web request. This will attempt to return a JSON or throw a web.

Parameters:

response (requests.Response) – The request response that is returned from a HTTP request

Returns:

A JSON dictionary data from the text in the response

Return type:

dict

nominalpy.connection.http.patch_request(credentials: Credentials, url: str, data: str = None, params: dict = {}) → dict

Creates a PATCH request with some suffix URL data and returns the result of the request in a JSON form. If there was an error, then a None will be returned. This requires valid credentials to be passed through.

Parameters:

  • credentials (Credentials) – The valid API credentials to make the API call with

  • url (str) – The sub-URL to make the HTTP PATCH request to, added to the credentials URL

  • data (str) – A set of data optional parameters that are passed into the request

  • params (dict) – A dictionary of values to parse into the PATCH request with associated values

Returns:

Creates a POST request with some suffix URL data and returns the result of the request in a JSON form. If there was an error, then a None will be returned. This requires valid credentials to be passed through.

Parameters:

Creates a PUT request with some suffix URL data and returns the result of the request in a JSON form. If there was an error, then a None will be returned. This requires valid credentials to be passed through.

Parameters:

nominalpy.connection.http.validate_credentials(credentials: Credentials) → None

Creates a GET request to test if the credentials are valid by calling the root directory of the URL passed through the credentials. This can be used to validate whether the API is live.

Parameters:

credentials (Credentials) – The credential information that needs to be validated
